sen.j: 桑山 重晴（くわやま しげはる）は、安土桃山時代の武将。
sen.e: Shigeharu KUWAYAMA was a Japanese military commander in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Shigeharu KUWAYAMA was a Japanese military commander who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 用語リストのレビュー結果を参照し、"who lived during"としました。
sen.e: Shigeharu KUWAYAMA was a Japanese military commander who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.e: He was from Owari Province.
He was from Owari Province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He was from Owari Province.

sen.j: 茶道でもあり、千利休から茶道を学んでいる。
sen.e: He was also a master of the tea ceremony and learned the tea ceremony from SEN no Rikyu.
sen.cmt: 初めの「茶道」は「茶人」と解釈しました。

sen.j: 大永4年（1524年）、尾張国海東郡桑山ノ庄で桑山以則の子として生まれた。
sen.e: He was born the son of Mochinori (以則) KUWAYAMA in Kuwayama no sho (manor in Kuwayama), Kaito District, Owari Province in 1524.
sen.cmt: 「桑山以則」の読み不明
sen.e: In 1524, he was born as the son of Mochinori KUWAYAMA in Kuwayama no sho, Kaito County, Owari Province.
sen.cmt: 海東郡→Kaito County[用語リストの指示に従い、「郡」を"County"に変更しました]桑山ノ庄→Kuwayama no sho[固有名詞なので、説明の英訳は削除しました]子として→as the son["as"が抜けておりましたので、付け加えました]
sen.e: In 1524, he was born as the son of Mochinori KUWAYAMA in Kuwayama no sho, Kaito County, Owari Province.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 桑山家は鎌倉幕府の有力御家人・結城朝光の子孫であるとされる。
sen.e: It is said that the Kuwayama family was a descendant of Tomomitsu YUKI, a senior vassal of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
It is believed that the Kuwayama family was a descendant of Tomomitsu YUKI, senior vassal of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: ～とされる→be believed["be said"は、「～といわれている」の意味であり、意味が違うので、変更しました]
sen.e: It is believed that the Kuwayama family was a descendant of Tomomitsu YUKI, senior vassal of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 織田信長の家臣・丹羽長秀に与力として仕え、姉川の戦いなどで活躍し、豊臣秀吉から冷静沈着な戦いぶりを賞賛された。
sen.e: Serving as a yoriki (mounted warrior belonged to a general in the Sengoku period) for Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of Nobunaga ODA, he performed brilliantly in the battles such as the Battle of Anegawa and then was praised by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI for his calm and reassuring performance.

Serving Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of Nobunaga ODA, as a yoriki (mounted warrior belonging to a general in the Sengoku period), he played an active role in the battles such as the Battle of Anegawa and so on, and was praised by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI for his level and calm activities.
sen.cmt: 人に～として仕える→serve someone as ～[「人に仕える」場合は、"serve someone"となるので、変更しました]冷静沈着な→level and calm[Eudictより]
sen.e: Serving Nagahide NIWA, a vassal of Nobunaga ODA, as a yoriki (mounted warrior belonging to a general in the Sengoku period), he played an active role in the battles such as the Battle of Anegawa and so on, and was praised by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI for his level and calm activities.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 天正2年（1574年）に秀吉の要請を受けて丹羽氏から羽柴氏へ移り、天正8年（1580年）には但馬国竹田城の城主となって1万石を与えられた。
sen.e: In 1574, he was transferred to the Hashiba clan from the Niwa clan at Hideyoshi's request.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After being transferred from the Niwa clan to the Hashiba clan at Hideyoshi's request in 1574, he became the lord of the Takeda-jo Castle in Tajima Province and was granted properties yielding 10,000 koku (approximately 1,803.9 cubic meters of crop yields) in 1580.
sen.cmt: 特に分割する必要がないと判断し、一文に変更しました。これに伴い、Wikipediaを参照し、原文を元に戻しました。１万石を与えられた→granted properties bearing 10,000 koku (approximately 1,803.9 cubic meters of crop yields)[「１万石を得られる領地を与えられた」の意味となるので、"properties"を入れ、また、「1万石」の説明の英訳を追加しました]
sen.e: After being transferred from the Niwa clan to the Hashiba clan at Hideyoshi's request in 1574, he became the lord of the Takeda-jo Castle in Tajima Province and was granted properties yielding 10,000 koku (approximately 1,803.9 cubic meters of crop yields) in 1580.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 天正11年（1583年）の賤ヶ岳の戦いでは賤ヶ岳砦を佐久間盛政の攻撃から死守するなどの武功を挙げ、2万石に加増された。
sen.e: His salary was increased to 20,000-koku because he performed military exploits such as protecting the Shizugatake fortress from the Morimasa SAKUMA's attack in the Battle of Shizugatake in 1583.

As a result of additional properties due to his military exploits such as defending the Fort Shizugatake at all cost against Morimasa SAKUMA's attack in the Battle of Shizugatake in 1583, he came to possess properties yielding 20,000 koku (approximately 3,607.8 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 賤ヶ岳砦→the Fort Shizugatake「2万石」の説明の英訳を追加しました]
sen.e: As a result of additional properties due to his military exploits such as defending the Fort Shizugatake at all cost against Morimasa SAKUMA's attack in the Battle of Shizugatake in 1583, he came to possess properties yielding 20,000 koku (approximately 3,607.8 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 天正13年（1585年）、紀州征伐の後に秀吉の弟・豊臣秀長が紀伊国の領主になると、同年5月に大坂城で秀吉から秀長の家老職を命ぜられ、3万石への加増を受けて和歌山城代となった。
sen.e: When Hideyoshi's younger brother Hidenaga TOYOTOMI became the lord of Kii Province in 1585 after the conquest of Kishu, he was appointed by Hideyoshi to Karo shoku (chief retainer) for Hidenaga in the Osaka-jo Castle in May of the year and became the Jodai (keeper) of the Wakayama-jo Castle with the salary increase to 30,000-koku.

When Hideyoshi's younger brother, Hidenaga TOYOTOMI, became the lord of Kii Province in 1585 after the conquest of Kishu, Shigeharu was appointed to a position of Karo (chief retainer) of Hiednaga by Hideyoshi at the Osaka-jo Castle in May of the same year, and became the keeper of Wakayama-jo Castle with properties increased to those yielding 30,000 koku (approximately 5,411.7 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 3万石への加増された→properties increased to those yielding 30,000 koku in total [「総計3万石となる領地を追加で与えられた」の意味なので、変更し、「3万石」の説明の英訳を追加しました]
sen.e: When Hideyoshi's younger brother, Hidenaga TOYOTOMI, became the lord of Kii Province in 1585 after the conquest of Kishu, Shigeharu was appointed to a position of Karo (chief retainer) of Hiednaga by Hideyoshi at the Osaka-jo Castle in May of the same year, and became the keeper of Wakayama-jo Castle with properties increased to those yielding 30,000 koku (approximately 5,411.7 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年）7月8日、豊臣秀次が謀反の疑いを釈明するために伏見城を訪れた際、伏見城大手門の守備を任された。
sen.e: On July 8, 1595, when Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI who was suspected of a rebellion visited the Fushimi-jo Castle to explain himself, Shigeharu was assigned to guard the Ote-mon Gate of the Fushimi-jo Castle.
On August 13, 1595, Shigeharu was assigned to guard the Main Gate of Fushimi-jo Castle when Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI visited Fushimi-jo Castle to account for suspicion of rebellion.
sen.cmt: 「伏見城大手門の守備を任された」が主文となるので、順序を入れ換えました。文禄4年（1595年）7月8日→August 13, 1595[旧暦表記でしたので、新暦に変更しました]大手門→Main Gate[作業指示書一式の"Dos and Don'ts for the Kyoto Project"第3項目、Be careful not to "romanize" Japanese terms unnecessarily、に従い、変更しました]
sen.e: On August 13, 1595, Shigeharu was assigned to guard the Main Gate of Fushimi-jo Castle when Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI visited Fushimi-jo Castle to account for suspicion of rebellion.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: その功により、和泉国日根郡谷川に1万石を加増されて4万石となった。
sen.e: In recognition of his service, he received the additional fief of Tanigawa, Hine District, Izumi Province yielding 10,000-koku and his salary was increased to 40,000-koku.

As a result of additional properties in Tanigawa, Hine County, Izumi Province yielding 10,000 koku which were granted in recognition of his service, he came to possess properties yielding 40,000 koku (approximately 7,215.6 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 簡潔な表現にするため、「石高」を主語としました。
sen.e: As a result of additional properties in Tanigawa, Hine County, Izumi Province yielding 10,000 koku which were granted in recognition of his service, he came to possess properties yielding 40,000 koku (approximately 7,215.6 cubic meters of crop yields) in total.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 慶長元年（1596年）に出家し、以後は桑山治部卿法印を名乗る。
sen.e: In 1596, he entered into priesthood and since then, he called himself Jibukyo Hoin (Minister of Civil Administration with the highest priesthood rank) KUWAYAMA.
After entering into priesthood in 1596, he called himself Kuwayama Jibukyo Hoin (Minister of Civil Administration with the highest priesthood rank).

sen.j: 同年5月11日に修理職の官位を嫡孫の桑山一晴に譲り、一晴に2万石、次男の桑山元晴に1万石を分与し、重晴は1万石のみを治めた。
sen.e: On May 11 of the year, he handed over the post of Shuri shiki (an official in the Office of Palace Repairs) to his legitimate grandson Kazuharu KUWAYAMA and governed only the fief of 10000-koku after allocating 20,000-koku and 10,000-koku to Kazuharu and the second son Motoharu KUWAYAMA, respectively.

sen.e: On June 6 of the same year, he handed over the post of Shurishiki (an official in the Office of Palace Repairs) to his legitimate grandson, Kazuharu KUWAYAMA, and governed only properties yielding 10000-koku as a result of distributing properties yielding 20,000 koku and 10,000 koku to Kazuharu, and to the second son, Motoharu KUWAYAMA, respectively.

sen.e: On June 6 of the same year, he handed over the post of Shurishiki (an official in the Office of Palace Repairs) to his legitimate grandson, Kazuharu KUWAYAMA, and governed only properties yielding 10000-koku as a result of distributing properties yielding 20,000 koku and 10,000 koku to Kazuharu, and to the second son, Motoharu KUWAYAMA, respectively.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦いの後、一晴から4,000石、元晴から2,000石を譲り受け、1万6,000石を治めることとなった。
sen.e: After the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he governed the fief of 16,000-koku, taking over 4,000-koku and 2,000-koku from Kazuharu and Motoharu, respectively.

After the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, he came to govern properties yielding 16,000 koku (approximately 2,886.24 cubic meters of crop yields) as a result of taking over properties yielding 4,000 koku (approximately 721.56 cubic meters of crop yields) and 2,000 koku (approximately 360.78 cubic meters of crop yields) from Kazuharu and Motoharu, respectively.
